A disjunctive syllogism is an argument where one premise is negative and the other affirmative, and the conclusion is negative; it asserts that if one is true, then the other cannot be. (e.g., "Either B or C is false; C is true; therefore, B is false.")

I ⊃ H      Hypothetical syllogism 2, 4  10. 1. M ⊃ N 2. O ⊃ P 3. N ⊃ P 4. (N ⊃ P⊃ (M v O) /∴N v P 5. M v O     Modus ponens 3, 4 6. N v P      Constructive dilemma 1, 2, 5  11. 1. A v (B ⊃ A) 2. ~A ⋅ C /∴ ~B 3. ~A        Simplification 2 4. B ⊃ A      Disjunctive syllogism 1, 3 5. ~B        Modus tollens 3, 4  12. 1. (D v E) ⊃ (F ⋅ G) 2. D  /∴ F 3. D v E       Addition 2 4. F ⋅ G       Modus ponens 1, 3 5. F          Simplification 4  13. 1. T ⊃ U 2. V v ~U 3. ~V ⋅ ~W /∴ ~T 4. ~V        Simplification 3 5. ~U        Disjunctive syllogism 2, 4 6.
Introduction to Logic and Critical Thinking, by Matthew Van Cleave
